SafetyInspectionBy: City of Atlanta, Department of Watershed Mgt.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Chlorine Institute Guidelines and U.S. DOT 49 CFR Requirements
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Prior to being placed in storage, all containers are visually inspected by Brenntag personnel to ensure that no damage has occurred during transportation and that there are no leaks.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Chlorine Institute Emergency Kit A or the Chlorine Recovery (Salvage) Vessel for cylinders.  Chlorine Institute Emergency Kit B for ton containers.
_prev_prog_2.Description: MSDS's for each of the two covered chemicals are kept on file at this facility or the Brenntag Mid-South Intranet.  Equipment specifications are kept at this facility for equipment that is used to store or transport these chemicals.  Equipment inspection and periodic maintenance is conducted in accordance with company procedures.  Unloading/loading of regulated chemicals is covered in our Operations Procedure Manual and Safety Code Book.  Materials of construction for containers of chlorine are located in the Chlorine Institute pamphlets.   Employee training on handling, loading/unloading and emergency response procedures is conducted on a routine basis.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Chlorine Institute Guidelines and U.S. DOT 49 CFR Requirements
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Prior to being placed in storage, all containers are visually inspected by Brenntag personnel to ensure that no damage has occurred during transportation and that there are no leaks.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Chlorine Institute Emergency Kit A or the Chlorine Recovery (Salvage) Vessel for cylinders.  Chlorine Institute Emergency Kit B for ton containers.
_prev_prog_2.Description: MSDS's for each of the two covered chemicals are kept on file at this facility or the Brenntag Mid-South Intranet.  Equipment specifications are kept at this facility for equipment that is used to store or transport these chemicals.  Equipment inspection and periodic maintenance is conducted in accordance with company procedures.  Unloading/loading of regulated chemicals is covered in our Operations Procedure Manual and Safety Code Book.  Materials of construction for sulfur dioxide containers are mandated by the U.S. Department of Transportation.  Employee training on handling, loading/unloading and emergency response procedures is conducted on a routine basis.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES: We at Brenntag Mid-South, Inc.

are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety and protection. This commitment is

inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design,

installation, operating procedures, maintenance and employee training associated with the processes at this

facility. It is our goal and objective to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of

regulated substances. If an accidental release were to occur, Brenntag has coordinated emergency response

activities with the Fulton County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the East Point Fire Department.

2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE & THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED: Our facility's primary activities

encompass Distribution of chemical products. Currently, there are two regulated substances present at this

facility that exceed the Threshold Quantity (TQ) as defined within 40 CFR 68.130. These substances include

Chlorine, and Sulfur Dioxide (anhydrous). These regulated substances at our facility are received prepackaged

in cylinders and ton containers. Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide are used only for resell to our customers.

3. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM: Our facility has taken necessary steps to

comply with the accidental release prevention requirements as set forth under 40 CFR Part 68. While the

two RMP regulated substances are also listed under OSHA's Process Safety Management Appendix A as set

forth under 29 CFR 1910.119, this facility does not have any PSM covered processes. The following sections

briefly describe the elements of our release prevention program that are currently in place at this facility.

a). Process Safety Information: Brenntag maintains a detailed record of written safety information that

describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all regulated

process

es.

b). Process Hazard Analysis (PHA's): This facility conducts comprehensive PHA's to ensure that hazards

associated with each regulated process are identified and controlled efficiently. The What If Techniques are utilized for completion PHA's. The PHA's are completed by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations. PHA's are reviewed prior to the implementation of any process change that involves the regulated substance; immediately following an accidental release or if an incident has occurred that could have resulted in an accidental release. At a minimum, PHA's are revalidated every five years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

c). Operating Procedures: For the purpose of safely conducting activities within our covered processes,

Brenntag maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation

such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdowns, emergency

operations, normal shutdown and startup following a turnaround. Operating procedures are regularly

evaluated and are accessible to all applicable employees involved within each regulated process.

d). Training: Brenntag has a comprehensive training program to ensure that employees are competent in

the operating and safety procedures associated with the each regulated process. New employees receive

basic training in process operations and safety procedures, followed by on-the-job supervision until they are

deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training is provided whenever there has been a

change in the process or at a minimum once every 3 years.

e). Mechanical Integrity: Brenntag conducts inspections and maintenance on process equipment to ensure

on-going equipment integrity. Qualified personnel receive specialized training to ensure that process

equipment is properly inspected and maintained. Any equipment deficiencies are corrected

in a safe and

timely manner.

f). Management of Change: Written procedures are in place at Brenntag to manage change in process

chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Applicable Brenntag personnel whose job task are

affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly informed and trained of such changes to

ensure safe and efficient implementation.

g). Pre-Startup Reviews: Brenntag conducts, when applicable, pre-startup safety reviews for new processes

and modifications to existing processes. These reviews are conducted to verify that construction, equipment,

operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup of the process.

h). Compliance Audits: Brenntag conducts compliance audits to determine whether the provisions, as set

forth under the RMP regulation, are being adhered to at this facility. These audits are conducted at least

every three years as required per this regulation. Corrective action, resulting from the audit, will be

implemented in a safe and prompt manner.

i). Incident Investigation: Brenntag will investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably

have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the mitigating circumstances surrounding the incident, as well as, to identify any corrective actions

that need implemented to prevent such incident from reoccurring. All incident investigations are retained for

a minimum of five years as required per this regulation.

j). Employee Participation: Brenntag truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention

is a team effort. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident

prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all

information created as part of the facility's implementation efforts to this standard.

k). Contractors: On occasion, this facility hires contractors to conduct

specialized maintenance and

construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, an evaluation of the contractor safety performance

will be conducted. Brenntag has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards that

is related to the contractors work area within the facility.  Contractors are also informed of all applicable

procedures for emergency response and facility evacuation in the event of an accidental release.

4. Five-Year Accident History: Brenntag has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the

last five years. Due to our stringent release prevention policies and employee training, there have been no

accidental releases during this period.

5. Emergency Response Plan: Brenntag has developed a written emergency response plan to address the

potential for accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response

including spill response and cleanup, first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local

emergency response agencies and the public. This plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes

that have taken place within our facility. Our emergency response plan has been coordinated and verified

with the Fulton County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

6. Planned Changes To Improve Safety: At this time, no changes are required at this facility.
